awd_titl_txt: Next Generation Electrochemistry (NGenE): A Summer Research Institute
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION 
Next Generation Electrochemistry (NGenE) are week-long student-centered summer intensive workshops that explore the frontiers of electrochemical research, which is at the core of many modern technologies. The event brings together a group graduate students with demonstrated interest and research experience in the field of electrochemistry with renowned electrochemists from across North America. The primary objective of the activity is to present fundamental questions and research at the frontiers of the field, and develop innovative strategies to address current gaps through collaboration and critical thinking. The format of NGenE is designed to accelerate advances at the frontier of electrochemistry in the United States, while developing a close-knit community of collaborators intent on tackling the most important fundamental questions with a direct impact on society, for instance, through novel energy technologies. The fundamental aspects presented by the instructors are broadly relevant, often applicable in other sub-fields of electrochemical research. A salient feature of the structure of NGenE is to contribute to the training of the next generation of electrochemists, fostering their critical thinking, and providing the tools to identify and tackle pioneering research priorities that produce meaningful societal advances through economic and environmental benefits.

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION
Next Generation Electrochemistry (NGenE) brings approximately 40 advanced graduate students and 10 distinguished lecturers together for five days to explore the frontiers of our scientific knowledge in electrochemistry. They examine fundamental phenomena that control the reactivity, transport and stability of electrochemical processes at an advanced level, identifying critical gaps in our understanding and innovative strategies to address them. NGenE explores these research frontiers through lectures, discussions and demonstrations, including a site visit to cutting-edge facilities at Argonne National Laboratory, as well as research projects developed by students under the mentoring of NGenE faculty. Faculty stimulate discussion by bringing unsolved challenges at the frontiers of electrochemistry to the fore, while working with students to develop and design innovative, forward-looking synthesis, characterization, theory, and simulation to solve problems in electrochemical science. The activity assumes baseline knowledge and prior experience in electrochemistry. As a result, NGenE does not ask, "What is electrochemistry?" but instead "What will electrochemistry become?" This focus on the fundamental knowledge gaps distinguishes NGenE from other summer workshops in electrochemistry. The goal of the activity is to stimulate a dialog between the current and the next generation of scientists in electrochemistry that spurs, in the future, an accelerated development of electrochemical science impacting applications in energy, medicine and manufacturing. This outcome would provide a clear societal benefit and contribute to the leadership of the US in this important discipline.

por.por_cntn:
With support from the Crosscutting program in the Division of Materials Research of the National Science Foundation, the University of Illinois at Chicago has organized a total of six yearly editions of Next Generation Electrochemistry (NGenE), from 2017 to 2022. NGenE is a student-centered, intensive summer workshop that explores the frontiers of electrochemical research, which is at the core of many modern technologies such as batteries or the artificial leaf.

NGenE recruits nationally a group of graduate students and young postdoctoral researchers with demonstrated interest and research experience in the field of electrochemistry. It brings them together with a team of renowned electrochemists from across North America. Together, participants and faculty identify and articulate the most pressing unsolved challenges at the frontiers of research in electrochemical science and technology. The goal is for participants to explore the boundaries of the field, as opposed to focusing on the details of what is already known. Thus, NGenE does not ask "What is electrochemistry?" but instead "What will electrochemistry become?". All in all, NGenE has contributed throughout its editions to the training of the next generation of electrochemists, fostering their critical thinking and collaboration, while providing the tools to identify and tackle pioneering research priorities that produce meaningful societal advances through economic and environmental benefits.

The primary theme of NGenE changes annually. The program assumes baseline knowledge and prior experience in electrochemistry. NGenE lectures prioritize: i) the discussion of unsolved roadblocks in electrochemistry that the coming generations will need to address, and ii) the identification of potential innovative approaches to solve them. The program is structured to last one week and take place in person at the University of Illinois at Chicago. The lectures are supplemented with sessions for participant networking and demonstrations of cutting-edge experimental capabilities.Furthermore, one day is reserved for a visit to Argonne National Laboratory for lectures and visits to unique facilities, a first for many participants.

The format in person was followed in 2017 to 2019, and in 2022. But NGenE did not stop during the peak of the COVID-19 pandemic. In 2020 and 2021, NGenE was held in an online format involving panel discussions with the best leaders in the field. NGenE participants were invited to contribute to the panel discussion, generating very vigorous conversations between established and budding researchers. Furthermore, the event was livecast through YouTube to anyone in the world interested in watching. The videos of the two online editions of NGenE are permanently available on YouTube.

Participants and faculty are encouraged to spend significant time talking and developing relationships that may become long term bonds. NGenE has impacted over 165 alumni from 46 different institutions. Alumni come from diverse backgrounds. In 2022, 47% were female or nonbinary, 53% were minority (Asian, Black/African, other), and 20% were
Latino/a/x. Many already have impactful careers in industry, academia, government and national laboratories and significant influence in shaping the foundations and strategic directions of electrochemical science in the U.S. and around the world more broadly. The conclusions of our
program have been highlighted in professional publications, including in the peer-reviewed literature. This program has now reached maturity and a recognized presence in the research community.
